Package infodynamics.measures.discrete

Class ActiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.discrete.InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
      • infodynamics.measures.discrete.ContextOfPastMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
        • infodynamics.measures.discrete.SingleAgentMeasureDiscreteInContextOfPastCalculator
          • infodynamics.measures.discrete.ActiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SingleAgentMeasureDiscrete, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    public class ActiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete
extends SingleAgentMeasureDiscreteInContextOfPastCalculator
implements EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    Active Information Storage calculator for univariate discrete (int[]) data. See definition of Active Information Storage (AIS) by Lizier et al. below. Basically, AIS is the mutual information between the past state of a time-series process X and its next value. The past state at time n is represented by an embedding vector of k values from X_n backwards, each separated by \tau steps, giving X^k_n = [ X_{n-(k-1)\tau}, ... , X_{n-\tau}, X_n]. We call k the embedding dimension, and \tau the embedding delay (only delay = 1 is implemented at the moment). AIS is then the mutual information between X^k_n and X_{n+1}.

    Usage of the class is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator: ActiveInformationCalculatorDiscrete(int, int);
    2. Initialise the calculator using initialise();
    3. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using one or more calls to sets of addObservations(int[]) methods, then
    4. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average entropy: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • local entropy values, such as SingleAgentMeasureDiscreteInContextOfPastCalculator.computeLocal(int[]);
      • and variants of these.
    5. As an alternative to steps 3 and 4, the user may undertake standalone computation from a single set of observations, via e.g.: SingleAgentMeasureDiscreteInContextOfPastCalculator.computeLocal(int[]), SingleAgentMeasureDiscreteInContextOfPastCalculator.computeAverageLocal(int[]) etc.
    6. Return to step 2 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • J.T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A.Y. Zomaya, "Local measures of information storage in complex distributed computation", Information Sciences, vol. 208, pp. 39-54, 2012.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int numPermutationsToCheck)
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the AIS would look like, under a null hypothesis that the past k values of our samples had no relation to the next value.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for an MI (like the AIS).

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(int[], int[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate AIS calculations.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of AIS scores under this null hypothesis.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int[][] newOrderings)
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the AIS would look like, under a null hypothesis that the previous k values of our samples had no relation to the next value in the time-series.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for AIS as a mutual information. Basically, the marginal PDFs of the past k values, and that of the next value, are preserved, while their joint PDF is destroyed, and the distribution of AIS under these conditions is generated.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of AIS scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public AnalyticMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an analytic distribution of what a given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE as per the references below.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        • Brillinger, "Some data analyses using mutual information", Brazilian Journal of Probability and Statistics, 18, p. 163, (2004)
        • Cheng et al., "Data Information in Contingency Tables: A Fallacy of Hierarchical Loglinear Models", Journal of Data Science, 4, p. 387 (2006).
        • Geweke, "Measurement of Linear Dependence and Feedback between Multiple Time Series", Journal of the American Statistical Association, 77, p. 304-313 (1982).
        • Barnett and Bossomaier, "Transfer Entropy as a Log-likelihood Ratio", Physical Review Letters, 109, p. 138105+ (2012).
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        the analytic distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computePastValue

        public int computePastValue​(int[] x,
                            int t)
        Utility function to compute a unique number to represent the combined past values of x up to and including time step t: (i.e. (x_{t-k+1}, ... ,x_{t-1},x_{t})) See TransferEntropyCalculatorDiscrete.getPastCount(int) for how the joint value representing the past is calculated.
        Overrides:
        computePastValue in class ContextOfPastMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
        Parameters:
        x - time series
        t - time step at which to compute the combined past
        Returns:
        an int representing the joint state of the past of x, x[t]^k

      • computePastValue

        public int computePastValue​(int[][] data,
                            int column,
                            int t)
        Utility function to compute a unique number to represent the combined past values of x (which is a column in data) up to and including time step t: (i.e. (x_{t-k+1}, ... ,x_{t-1},x_{t})) See TransferEntropyCalculatorDiscrete.getPastCount(int) for how the joint value representing the past is calculated.
        Overrides:
        computePastValue in class ContextOfPastMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
        Parameters:
        data - 2D time series, first index is time, second is variable number
        column - column of data which is variable x
        t - time step at which to compute the combined past
        Returns:
        an int representing the joint state of the past of x, x[t]^k
